course.subject: ISOM
course.name: Business Applications Development in Python
course.description: This course introduces programing concepts and applications with Python programming language. The applications are mainly in the domain of business analytics. The course covers topics including general programming concepts, object-oriented design, and external Python packages for data manipulation, visualization and analytics.

reviews.author: toxicustjj
reviews.title: Only who know python already are recommended to reg this course
reviews.comment_content:
Basic python with some data analytics skills(NumPy, panda, matplotlib, web scraping)
Seems good by just look at the syllabus, but there is no PowerPoint slide and just use ipynb files with pdf, which is not convenient to use or do revision.
Overall, the content is fair but the delivery is really bad.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Jia Jia's English is hard to understand with the accent and seems he has difficulty organizing what he wants to say. Maybe he can express himself better through coding rather than verbal language.
The lectures only go through some simple examples which you will not be able to manage your assignments and exams as there can be infinite variables changed and become way more complicated.

For TA, good luck if you have Samual Yeung. So chill in the tutorial that he even told us to google and not answering questions about assignments. Feel hopeless if you really have trouble doing the exercises. Chill for him, hell for you.
reviews.comment_grading:
In-class exercise@5: 20% [mean=18/20]
Usually, Jia Jia will go through everything with you if time allows. If not enough time, do it yourself and this part is not difficult.

Assignment@2: 40% [mean of Assignment 1 = 95/100, Assignment 2 = 94/100]
Quite difficult if you have no prior experience. Assignment 1 is fine. (I got mean).
Assignment 2 is really a mess that you cannot get what you need through lecture notes. You need to GitHub and StackOverflow a lot, but there are restrictions that you cannot use materials outside the lecture. So, it is so hard to finish, and it takes a lot of time even you can do it. (I only managed to finish 80% and get around 70/100)

Final exam: 40% [didn't release score]
2 hours for 4 coding tasks. Even more difficult than assignments and you wouldn't be able to finish on time. As a python beginner, even I study hard and attend all lectures, I can only finish about half of the exam. The expression of question is messy and hard to understand what's happening. And some of the finished parts have errors that are not taught how to solve. Feel so frustrated and expected to get about 25-30/100 for the exam.

Heard that mean is around B-, expect to have C  or C- in my situation. [**UPDATED: Surprisingly, the grade is not extremely bad. Finally got a C+ and it's better than my expectation.**] Really not recommend for python beginners as there is not much you can learn from the lectures and you will be suffered from a bad grade and frustration when dealing with assignments and final. If you are eager to learn python, there are many online courses that work way better than this.
reviews.comment_workload:
The 5 In-class exercises need to be submitted 1 day after released. but usually not complicated and hard.

About a week for assignments, but really time consuming and tough to finish.

The Final is extremely difficult and please don't expect to do well even you did a detailed revision.

Overall, things keep coming and hard for beginners to handle. Maybe the experienced feel better that there is no group exercise or project.

reviews.author: Anyone HAHA
reviews.comment_content: tbh, at the start of the whole course, he told us to use google to search for more information to learn about Python. He is not wrong but he has got no content for teaching about different functions, attributes those kind of things. The way you learn for the content is just self learning through looking at the example code files and browse the internet. Very unclear instructions about the content that he change it from time to time. Very hard time to follow
reviews.comment_teaching: Very boring and not fun. Just listening to a robot speaking. Just reading through the slides. Because he may realize that his course is really boring, he will put the quiz at the last of the lecture to force you listen to lecture which make you very annoyed.
reviews.comment_grading:
Again very unclear instructions. finish the basic requirements of solving the problem stated is a must, he also wants additional things such as user-friendliness, ease to read which is still reasonable. But when comes to presenting your own program for the assignment, he will tell you to make interesting video which need you the edit or add effects on it which is very time consuming and totally not related to any learning outcomes in this course.
The inclass exercise is also terrible, he has no time management at all that he only give very tight time for you to finish your work and it is quite time consuming to zip the file and submit to canvas so you dont have much time left or you will be late submission if you aim for fulfilling all task requirement and test them.
He also made tonnes of mistakes in the question files which is very confusing and he only give for 1 or 2 mins for you to amend the whole file becuz of his mistakes which is totally not enough.
reviews.comment_workload: Annoying workload but from time to time you have test for your own program for your assignment so it will take your time at a regular frequency but not only once before each deadline. He didn't read your assignment clearly so you will usually get a worse grade than you think. Even if you try to appeal it, he shows you a very non willing attitude on trying to regrade it again

reviews.author: belowmeanguy
reviews.title: Don't enroll in Jiajia's lecture if you want to actually learn
reviews.comment_content:
- Python basics
- For loop, while loop
- Def function, lambda
- Web scraping
- Panda
- Numpy
- Matplotlib

Course content is challenging for Python beginner, but easy if you have learnt Python before.
reviews.comment_teaching:
DO NOT ENROLL IN JIAJIA'S LECTURE IF YOU WANT TO ACTUALLY LEARN!!!

I know nothing about business analytics or real life applications after the whole semester. Jiajia only uses Jupyter Notebook to teach codes step by step, which can hardly give a full picture about 'Business Analytics'. Sure you can learn about coding skills, but don't expect to learn how to make your coding skills applicable.

Prof James uses VS Code, and his individual project sounds more meaningful (although he has other annoying problems lmao). Jiajia's individual assignment is just some random coding questions for you to solve.

Less and less students show up in Zoom lectures lmao. But it's no surprise as Jiajia just talk through the codes step by step. Attend the lectures if you don't understand the codes. Otherwise, you can just finish the lecture by yourself by reading through the codes within 30 mins lol.
reviews.comment_grading:
In-class exercises (40%):

Jiajia briefly talked about the In-class exercises using lecture time, and he would leave around half of the questions for you to finish and submit them to Canvas in the next day. Some questions are challenging, but you can browse Stack Overflow and just finish the exercises step by step. I got ~38% out of the 40% in total for 5 In-class exercises.

Individual Assignment (30%):
It's like an advanced version of the In-class exercises, included most of the topics you learnt throughout the semester. Again, just use Stack Overflow lol.

Final Exam (30%):
Super difficult. Total GG. The mean was just 3X%. Luckily, I scored above mean by quite a lot.

I really have to emphasize that relying only on course materials is absolutely NOT ENOUGH to get a good grade (unless you are a programming genius). I had an A at last. But I went online and did coding exercises very frequently. The course materials can only get you to learn the basics and some random examples.

My only advice is keep doing exercises online
reviews.comment_workload:
- 5 In-class exercises
- Individual assignment
- Final exam

Workload is very heavy if you are a python beginner. You need to do a lot of practices and exercises. If you are a genius, you may find this course easy. No attendance, no participation, just 5 in-class exercises to be submitted within two days, and an assignment with adequate time to finish.

But if you are stupid in programming like me, you definitely need more regular practices. Jiajia has some practice questions for each topic, but those are definitely not enough if you want to have a good grade in this course. Only relying on course materials may get you a low B or C range.

Hard work definitely pays off in this course, especially in doing Jiajia's questions. You can find all sorts of exercises online. Do as much as you can and you should find Jiajia's questions easy.

reviews.author: ming_ctm
reviews.title: 幾有用既一個python course
reviews.comment_content:
內容幾有用，可以分做2parts:
基本python syntax
- data structure (string, list, tuple, dict, etc)
- list comprehension
- if else
- for loop, while loop
- function and class

進階Libraries:
- matplotlib (plot graph)
- pandas (dataframe)
- sklearn (predictive model)
- keras (neural network)
reviews.comment_teaching:
James:
課程安排有少少混亂
頭大半個sem都係好咁慢教緊basic syntax
之後佢發現好似唔多夠時間，就rush左pandas同sklearn

Charles:
超熱心既TA，份人超好傾，好肯教好有耐性解答問題，分分鐘跟佢學得多過James，好到我都唔小心做左Charles打手添haha
reviews.comment_grading:
10% class group exercise
7次計最好個5次 基本上有做就滿分 class ex.個幾日會數人頭tick attendance 記得出現就ok
20% individual assignment
20% group assignment
50% final 淨係考basic syntax同pandas，個人覺得幾簡單 但mean得7x/100 可能教得太亂d人跟唔到

assignments同regrade後既exam都無出stat
靚唔靚grade係個迷 個人覺得符合預期
reviews.comment_workload:
成個course得3份assignments，有python底/識既話workload可以話係輕鬆，但對beginners黎講時間太少都幾chur😵 當時最少有半班都要搵Charles求救(當然我都係其中一個)

individual assignment*2
Part 1: 得3日時間 data exploration, visualization,同寫conclusions
雖然係為part 2做準備既 但最好當full report咁做 (一開始佢話比得3日唔expect太多 結果grade個陣就當report咁執 無conclusion個d 就即刻扣分) 利申:信左佢 瀨左野

Part 2: 7日時間 用d data 根據條情境題 做下data cleansing, exploration, visualization 同比下business suggestion

group assignment: 7日時間 做下data exploration, data cleansing, visualization 同整個predictive model(sklearn)

reviews.author: smellsshit
reviews.title: Enrolling in this course will cause retardation
reviews.comment_content:
Disclaimer: This post has nothing to go against genetic disorders, but can't find other words to describe due to my poor expression skills

Retarded course
Retarded TA
Retarded professor
Retarded assignments
Retarded exercises

This course is basically shit, teaching useless content which is extremely basic. the course called is helping students build good programming practices but turns out to be wasting time doing useless shit. You won't learn "Business Applications Development" after the course, I'll say it is way far from developing stuff.

3 modules:
Basic Python including class and dictionaries
Selenium
Flask
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is boring with many bullshits, teaching no useful practical content. Asking you to google everything.

I rage quit the lectures after the first class, don't want to hear his retarded voice. They didn't even cover all the techniques in the course materials, so if you want a good grade you must attend the classes or go through the recordings.

The TA and professor are extremely unhelpful, they will reply to inquiries with no manners, no matter in person or through email. And this nigga will reply to inquiry emails asking you to do the SFQ shamelessly,

Sadly this retarded professor teaches a lot of IS courses, please avoid this mf if possible.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading simply depends on the moods of the professor and TA, sometimes getting full marks with a shitty program, but in some cases, using the same shit will cause point deductions. And you won't score high if you use your own methods to achieve the tasks. You have no say in discussing whether it's a good program or not with them.

Overall >80% but getting a B-, saw previous reviews saying getting B+ at the same overall score.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is light if you have learned basic python before.
The group project is s meaningless as it's difficult to collab and build a program at this stage. and you have to record a presentation of the program, which makes the course even worse.

You have to learn intermediate HTML to score high in group projects, so I think that's why they changed the course name from python for business to business applications development. What's the point of using HTML from python?

reviews.author: mushroomwatcher
reviews.title: why not comp1021? (if u r not required to take this one)
reviews.comment_content: the content is designed to be practical, whereas too simple and basic to be used in real life / work
reviews.comment_teaching:
nice TA, handsome, soft and helpful
okay-level professor, lecture content actually less important than tutorial courses
reviews.comment_grading:
fucked-up grading
if a course has an overall mean score over 80% and it grades using curve, what can you expect?
reviews.comment_workload:
one big individual assignment and a group assignment with presentation.
three in-class exercises, best 2 of which count into final score
honesly not pretty much
but you need to practice a lot to truly understand if you are not a genius or something

reviews.author: hahahaahaaaaaah
reviews.title: A harsh course
reviews.comment_content:
1/3 of the course is about the basic python syntax
1/3 of the course is about Selenium
1/3 of the course content is about Flask
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching of James is quite boring. I spent most of the time watching the lecture video and skip to the key points
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading was quite bad.
1st assignment below mean
2nd assignment, in-class, mid term above mean
final exam 82%
final grade B
reviews.comment_workload:
A. Assignment (30%) (Individual and group)
There are TWO assignments, namely assignment 1, and assignment 2. Students are expected to apply Python programming skills to solve practical business application problems.
Assignment 1 (individual) - (15%)
This is an individual assignment. Each student needs to submit his/her program by the deadline. The detailed grading criteria will be stated clearly in the assignment document.
Assignment 2 (group) - (15%)
This is a group assignment. A pre-assigned group is required to design and develop a business application. The details will be announced later in the course. Student groups are required to make a video presentation (not more than 10 minutes).


B. In-class Exercise (30%) (Individual)
There are THREE in-class exercises throughout the semester, and they are all individual exercises. Count only the highest two exercises.

C. Final Exam (40%)
There is a Final Exam, which covers ALL topics taught in the semester. Further information will be
provided in the last class.

reviews.author: WayToGo
reviews.comment_content:
First half was about fundamental python programming skills including things learnt from isom 2020. Second half was about something new such as web automation and data visualisation, in which in my opinion is quite fun and useful.

Precise topics for each week:
Introduction to Python and Business Analytics
Data, data types and operators
Data structures: Lists and Tuples
Data structures: Dictionaries 1
Data structures: Dictionaries 2
Control statements: if 1
Control statements: if 2
Control statements: for, while
Control statements: try-except
Class Practice
In-class exercise 1
Functions and Classes 1
Functions and Classes 2
Functions and Classes 3
Functions and Classes 4
Web automation – Selenium 1
In-class exercise 2
Web automation – Selenium 2
Mid Term Break
Web automation – Selenium 3
Data Exploration 1 - pandas
Data Visualization 1 - pandas
In-class exercise 3
Data Exploration 2 - matplotlib
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Kwok is very nice. He is willing to adjust the syllabus and things to be tested according to our feedbacks and comments.

Ray is one of the best, if not the best, TA I have encountered in UST. He would offer extra help to students with no programming experience. And he usually replies to emails soon after you sent them to him.
reviews.comment_grading:
A. Assignment (30%) (Individual and group)

There are TWO assignments, namely assignment 1, and assignment 2. Students are expected to apply Python programming skills to solve practical business analytics problems.

Assignment 1 (individual) - (15%)

Assignment 2 (group) - (15%)

B. In-class Exercise (30%) (Individual)

There are THREE in-class exercises throughout the semester, and they are all individual exercises. Each student will have THREE in-class exercise scores, but only the BEST TWO scores will be counted toward the final grade.

C. Final Exam (40%)

There is a Final Exam, which covers ALL topics taught in the semester. Further information will be provided in the last class.

Comments: The grading is fair. Undeniably, there were some students who had experience using python before. But if you review after each class and seek for help from professor and TA when needed, I think you will be fine. The final grade is better than expectation.
reviews.comment_workload: For people like me who don't have programming experience before this course, the workload was quite huge as keeping up with other classmates was not easy. There were some optional exercises for everyone. I would work on those exercises after class.

reviews.author: wj
reviews.comment_content:
Introduction to Course and Programming
Introduction to Python and Business Analytics
Data, data types and operators
Data structures: Lists and Tuples
Data structures: Dictionaries
Control statements: if
Control statements: for, while, try statements
Functions and Classes 1
Functions and Classes 2
Web automation – Selenium 1
Web automation – Selenium 2
Data Visualization 1 - pandas
Data Visualization 2 - matplotlib
reviews.comment_teaching: In the first class, the professor asked us to Google for solution if we ran into problems regarding our Python program.
reviews.comment_grading:
In-class Exercise 14% (best 7 out of 9)
Assignment 40%
Final Exam 45%

9 in-class exercises, mixture of both individual and group exercises. There is one in-class exercise each week.

2 individual assignments. First assignment is to modify a sample program in order to make it work. Second assignment is to design and develop a Python program to crawl data from websites and store data in data files.

Final Exam is relatively difficult compared to other assessments.
reviews.comment_workload:
Simple, weekly in-class exercises
Time-consuming assignments

reviews.author: tomsonkwok
reviews.comment_content: Although the course title include business analytics, there is no enough time covering all the materials as stated in the syllabus. However, it is still solid enough for a Python beginner to learn about the program structure. Very easy to catch up for a programming beginner.
reviews.comment_teaching: Jia Jia usually spent too much time on explaining one single item in the slide, even though some points were quite simple. It may sometimes make the lectures boring. Due to the lengthy explanation, it may be hard to catch the main idea of it. If you can speak Mandarin, I would strongly recommend you to stay behind the lectures and ask your question in Mandarin to get a clearer picture.
reviews.comment_grading: Very good grade. Not much to mention.
reviews.comment_workload:
1 lab per week, attend all to get full marks easily.
5 individual assignments, spare 1-2 days and very likely you can get full marks.
No midterm but a final exam. It consisted of MCQs and fill-in-the-blank Qs. MCQs can be tricky and the fill-in-the-blank Qs were quite straight forward.

reviews.author: boosit
reviews.comment_content:
Basic Python Syntax
- Data, Data types, Operators
- Strings
- Lists, Tuples, Sets, Dictionaries
- Control Statements, Functions, Classes
(No recursion)

Libraries
- Data Manipulation/Visualization
   - Pandas
   - Matplotlib
   - Seaborn
- Predictive Models
   - Sklearn
   - Keras
reviews.comment_teaching:
Big issue with pacing since James took 3/4 of the term introducing syntaxes which would be 2-3 weeks max of content in a COMP course..... Ended up rushing through the rest of the course especially for keras.

Both James and Charles (TA) were very helpful though, would stay for hours after class answering questions
reviews.comment_grading:
10% In-class Exercise (Best of 5)
- Basically free points as long as you attend lectures

- Actually the most important part of the course IMO, since
1) 80% of the final are variations of in-class exercises
2) The questions are much harder than the ones in notes....

20% Individual Assignment
20% Group Assignment
- Basic Pandas Implementation
- While not hard, they're definitely time-consuming, would recommend starting early
- Follow the guideline and format closely

50% Final
- Not hard if you understand the exercises, but hand writing code is the most retarded thing ever
- Proofread your syntaxes and don't forget to add parentheses!!!

Grading is pretty lenient IMO
reviews.comment_workload:
Assignments
- Expect 1-2 days of work for each assignment

Overall, not high as long as you understand the content.

reviews.author: shining_days
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1: Intro. to Course and Programming
              Intro. to Python and Business Applications
              Data Processing 1: data, data types, operators
              Data Processing 2: List, Tuple, and Dictionary
              Data Validation: if-else, for, while, try-except
Week 2: Functions, Objects, Classes
              HTML, Web Scraping – BeautifulSoup
Week 3&4: Interactive Data Visualization with Plotly
                  Web App Development with Dash
reviews.comment_teaching: The instructor teaches clearly and do take care of our individual needs herself (as this is a small class with only 11 students). Just ask a question if you don't understand and she will try her best to help you. Or else if you just don't want to stop the class then just google it. Google is a good way to learn python.
reviews.comment_grading:
The instructor claims that it is absolute grading, but did not mention the cutoffs.
Evaluation:
A. After-class Exercise (20%)
2 exercises, 10% each
B. Assignment (30%)
2 individual assignments, 15% each
C. Final Exam (50%)

No statistics is given so you won't know how others perform.
I got 89.4% in total grades and got a B+. I guess you need at least 90% to get an A- or above?

For reference:
After class exercises: 94/100 & 100/100 >> 194/200
Assignments: 14/15 & 13/15 >> 27/30
Final Exam: 86/100

Also, there is one random attendance check on the 4th or 5th lesson, but I am not sure what is its use...
reviews.comment_workload:
I guess the workload is appropriate as a summer course.
There are two after-class exercises that have to be submitted before the end of the day and two assignments that are more complicated with a whole week before deadline.
The after class exercises are just a few tasks which can be done in around 2 hours given that you know what is going on in class.
The assignments are a simple project (compared to other courses) which you might have to invest more time to think and code if you have no prior coding experience other than ISOM2020/2600. But it really helps you to revise what you should have learnt in class so that you know what you are doing in the final exam.
However, the final exam is just two days after the final lesson. That's where the stress comes from.

reviews.author: Testing1234
reviews.title: Much better than expectation
reviews.comment_content:
Intro. to Course and Programming
Intro. to Python and Business Applications
Data Processing 1: data, data types, operators
Data Processing 2: List, Tuple, and Dictionary
Data Validation: if-else, for, while, try-except
Functions, Objects, Classes

HTML, Web Scraping – BeautifulSoup
Web Scraping – BeautifulSoup

Interactive Data Visualization with Plotly
Web App Development with Dash
Web App Development with Dash
Web App Development with Dash + Revision

I think the topics are helpful for business applications.
reviews.comment_teaching: Our lecturer is Luying (Iris) QIU, who is a Phd candidate. Her teaching is clear and detailed. She takes care of students with different programming background. She also provides different in-class exercises to make sure we can catch up on the topic. In general I love her teaching style.
reviews.comment_grading:
Since there are only 14 students in Summer semester, she said she will apply absolute grading. Therefore she didn't release statistics like mean or sd.

2 After-class Exercise  20% (10%+10%)
2 Individual Assignments  30% (15%+15%)
Final Exam  50%

For me:
After-class Exercise: 10%+10%
Individual Assignments: 14%+15%
Final Exam: 48.5%
Overall: 97.5%, A

To be honest I thought I can get an A+ under absolute grading, but it is fine cause the exams and assignments are easy. It is not feasible to give everyone an A range.
reviews.comment_workload:
Low.
You have to submit the after-class exercise before midnight after it is released. It contains around 7 questions which are very easy. You can finish them in half an hour.
The first part of the individual assignment is web scraping. The second part is Dash app development with a 1-page business report. Which are both easy and you can finish them in an hour.
The final exam is open book. You can read PDF files or handwritten notes. You'll write your answer on the exam paper, which contains 10 MCs and 4 LQs, all of the LQs are fill-in-the-blank questions. Personally me and my friends think the exam is pretty simple.

reviews.author: ohmygosh
reviews.title: Would be difficult if you don't have any programming background
reviews.comment_content:
Attendance: My professor don't take any attendance
Assignment: in-class exercise at the end of each chapter + 2 assignments + Final exam
Materials: the materials given by the professor are pretty detail so basically you can learn everything by yourself by reading through it
reviews.comment_teaching: Just go when you do not need to work on any other projects or courses
reviews.comment_grading:
for in-class exercise: everyone will get full marks
for assignment 1: full mark if you don't make any minor mistakes
for assignment 2: for this sem, it's on web scraping and dash for an election website, and I think it's very challenging, so I would say there's a chance that you might lose marks here
for final exam: it's the typical coding course type of exam with mc and some fill in the blanks and the difficulty level will depends
reviews.comment_workload: I would say there is not much things to do and it's pretty chill

reviews.author: bruh_moment
reviews.comment_content: I think it is too difficult for business students without programming background, especially during later half of the course about web scraping and flask. IMO too much time is focused on the basics of Python instead of actual business application development.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Jia isn't the best in speaking English, but it is enough to understand what he is talking about.
reviews.comment_grading: I am not sure. Since I already have some programming skills, I got a pretty good grade. Can't speak for others though. There are in-class exercises. Since Professor Jia always reveals the answers during class, not getting full mark is already below mean. So the main differentiation is probably the exam and the project. If you are lucky enough to have a good teammate, bonus mark of the project can partially contribute to other parts of the grading. Make sure to reg this course with a programmer friend XD
reviews.comment_workload:
2 Assignment:
1 of them is the group project, which is significantly more difficult than all other exercises. The other one is just python basics that is similar to the in-class exercise

5 in-class exercise
He will reserve half lesson to finish the in-class exercises with the students. So if you attend the session where he does the exercises, you don't have to allocate extra time for this.

Final:
Allow hard-copy notes

reviews.author: g
reviews.comment_content:
▪ Lectures on concepts, methods, examples, exercises, etc.
▪ Labs for more hands-ons practice and fast feedback (not mandatory)

Topics:
Introduction to Python and Business Analytics Python Basics: Data, Data types, and Operators
Data Structures: Lists, Tuples, and Dictionaries
Control Structures: if, for, while, and try statements
Functions and Classes
Web Scraping with Beautiful Soup and Selenium NumPy Arrays and Vectorized Computation
Data Wrangling with pandas
Data Visualization with matplotlib and seaborn Revision
reviews.comment_teaching: Jia jia is actually helpful if you attend the lectures regularly and ask him questions, but it may still be hard to understand if your background of python is not good because the course expects you to have a good understanding of python basics. As someone who is bad at python I can tell he tried to help but I still need to ask for friends' help and a lot of exercises to actually be able to learn about it.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme:
▪ 5 In-class exercises: 30%
▪ 1 individual assignment: 30%
▪ Final exam: 40%

Final exam is very similar to the in-class exercises and individual assignment and it is open book so it would be extremely helpful to bring all your exercises with you to the exam.
reviews.comment_workload:
The in-class exercises are time consuming and it would be require some drilling to complete it. Jia jia goes through the exercise in class but of course not every bit of it. But it helps to get started if you have no idea what to do. But definitely a lot better when you work together with friends.

Final exam was stressful too as you have to handwrite the answers and it's easy to make mistakes when you don't have the software with you.

reviews.author: SKIOR
reviews.title: Useful course and pretty good grade
reviews.comment_content:
Introduce Python and element of it. When it comes to the end of the semester, James will teach about selenium about the automation of website.

For students majored in Information System, should choose between Python, VBA and Java. I would say this course is the most difficult to master within these three courses, but all I would like to say, Python is the most popular programming language, and this is the most useful course among the three. You will definitely not regret.

"Python has recently become the most popular general-purpose programming language according to many polls among programmers. The scripting nature of Python allows fast development and easy maintenance of applications. More importantly, the unparalleled community support makes Python increasingly powerful. In this course, students will learn Python programming language in the context of business data analytics. With the explosion of electronic data available to organizations and the demand for better and faster decisions, data-driven intelligence becomes a key source of competitive advantage for business organizations. We believe that the combination of Python programming skills and business data analysis will provide high practical value to students majoring in Information Systems as well as other related fields."
reviews.comment_teaching:
Mixed-mode Lite

James would just teach the basic of each function in Python and expect students to learn more on YouTube. Students can learn what he/she interested. Lab session is important for this course, TA have a good teaching skill and willing to answer students' questions (my lab always delayed as the TA is still answering students' question for the last lab session, but for the content part of the lab never get overrun) Don't frustrate if not too familiar with Python, both James and the TA is willing to answer your question through email or on Zoom, and James will provide you extra Python file for practice or at least give you the link to the file.

For this course, not a harsh course, all you need to do is just attend the lectures, labs (even not watching YouTube videos I think it is not a big deal for your grades, imo review lecture videos is more important)
reviews.comment_grading:
- 2 Assignment (15% each, 30% counts towards your final grade)
- 3 In-class Exercise (only BEST 2 scores will be counted, 15% each. 30% counts towards your final grade)
- Final Exam (40%)

I would say the grade is fairly good. For me,

Assignment 1 15/15 (mean: 12.83, lower quartile: 12.83, higher quartile: 14.9)
Assignment 2 12.9/15 (mean: 12.89, lower quartile: 13.2, higher quartile: 12.5)

In-class exercise 1 12.8/15 (mean: 8.14, lower quartile: 9.85, higher quartile: 6.23)
In-class exercise 1 11.5/15 (mean: 9.57, lower quartile: 8.4, higher quartile: 11.5)

Final Exam 30.4/40 (mean: 27.74, lower quartile: 22.88, higher quartile: 33.35)

Finally got a B+
reviews.comment_workload:
First assignment is individual, code a program to imitate ATM. Including log-in account, create account, withdraw money, exchange currency etc. Not a difficult task, it takes around 3-4 days to get it done. Not to expect can do it in one night as your need to de-bug your program.

Second assignment is working in group. Basically, you need to automate website to generate different Excel file. The most difficult part of this assignment is your groupmate may use a different version of web Chrome driver, some function may not work the same on other version's web driver. Try to run your program on all groupmates' computers and make sure all it works.

For in-class exercise, it's just two easy questions, some code-line will already be provided, you just have to fill them all or add some function based on the question requirements.

For final examination, it is take-home exam for me since the pandemic, I'm not sure if it is the case when back to normal. Final exam is just like doing several in-class exercise which echoed together at the same time, time is enough.

reviews.author: Yiling
reviews.comment_content:
Content is a useful, almost full set of python knowledge, for self study is usefl

The teaching material is quite a lot, but I think is the overall course design.
Syllabus
Part 1: Python Basics
1: Introduction to Python
2: Python Basics
3: Python Basics 2—String
4: Python Data Structure
5: Python Data Structure - Dictionary
6: Python Control Structure
7: Python Function and Class

Part 2: Business Analytics
8: Python Pandas and Matplotlib
9: Python in Business Analytics 1
reviews.comment_teaching:
Speaking and lecture is an overall boring, but quick detail.
He elaborates quitein detail.
He provides enough exercise for us to study
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grade, didn't expect to have A+ with around 50% of exam question

almost all of us get 50/50 of the lab assignment

The assignement won't have answer, will only release grade
reviews.comment_workload: 4-5 lab, guide us on how to do during lecture , the exam weight more portion, one hw assignment (Individual)

reviews.author: Labba
reviews.comment_content:
The first half focuses on python basics, and the second half focuses on business analytics and machine learning using python.

Syllabus
Part 1: Python Basics
1: Introduction to Python
2: Python Basics
3: Python Basics 2—String
4: Python Data Structure
5: Python Data Structure - Dictionary
6: Python Control Structure
7: Python Function and Class

Part 2: Business Analytics
8: Python Pandas and Matplotlib
9: Python in Business Analytics 1
- Learn the basics of business analytics: important concepts, linear regression for continuous outcome, predictions, model evaluations, Scikit-learn package.
10: Python in Business Analytics 2
- Learn how to make predictions with categorical outcome (i.e., classification models).
11:  Python in Business Analytics 3
- Learn basics about text mining with Python: Data preparation; Vectorization of text; Classification model building and evaluation.
Bullet points:
reviews.comment_teaching:
Robin's teaching was clear and he was willing to answer your questions. However, since this is a Summer course, he might go through the content very quickly. You might feel overwhelmed if you do not already have any programming or python knowledge.  

But in his lectures, he gives us sufficient time to try to write the codes by ourselves.
reviews.comment_grading:
Lecture Participation - 10%
Lab Exercise - 30%
Assignment - 30%
Final Exam - 30%

Almost all people get full marks in lab exercises and the first assignment because you just need to follow the codes taught in class, but be careful while reading the questions.

Participation: full
Lab Exercise: almost full
Assignment: full
Final Exam: above mean ~1.5sd

Grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
Because this is a Summer course spanning 3 weeks, quite intensive if you don't have a programming background.

You just need to ask 2 questions for full participation. Lab exercises after every lecture, but they are quite easy. Assignments require some more work.

The final exam is the hardest. The first part is open-book MC, which is easier. The second part is coding, similar to the lab exercise. But they are harder because there're some difficult questions that you never met.

reviews.author: thanos
reviews.title: Unexpectedly good grades
reviews.comment_content:
First half is Python Basics ISOM 2020 stuff
But before you realize it, it would sudden get a lot more difficult
Topics included:
Numpy
Pandas
Web scrapping with Beautiful Soup and Selenium
Matplotlib

I think it's really useful, especially for web scrapping which saved me from manually drawing data one by one from websites
Matplotlib is another really handy tool to plot and tailor some decent graph for future presentations (finally sth save me from those terrible excel graphs, perhaps Idk how to use excel....)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Jia is very nice actually and beginner friendly. He uses Jupyter Notebook to teach codes step by step which I feel really good (cuz i got no knowledge about Python beforehand, except ISOM 2020)
A very patient gentleman

People with background in Python may feel bored
reviews.comment_grading:
Very Nice turns out to be
In-class Exercises (20% total for all 5 combined)
Individual Assignment (40%)
Final Exam (40%)

I guess most ppl get nearly full marks if not full marks in exercises and assignments
Only difference would be the final exam which have 4 long questions, each with a few sub questions and we need to answer them within 2 hours

Totally not enough time, don't even try to finish the whole paper, you won't succeed even with tens of hours spent on practicing (or maybe I'm just not good at Python)
Panik during exam
Final exam score is a mystery but eventually managed to secure an A range I don't know why

Jia Jia is really nice that's the only possible reason
reviews.comment_workload:
5 in-class exercise related to the most recent topic
1 individual assignment
1 final exam
No attendance
No participation
No groupwork
I agree that workload is heavy cuz I'm a python beginner.
need to do a lot of EXTRA practices and exercises to save the grades and get myself familiar with the functions.

In-class exercise should be done within 2 hours
Assignment to be handed in within 2 weeks
Suggestions:
Form a study group with classmates to help each other out cuz it's easy to get stuck

reviews.author: aaronic92351
reviews.title: Lenient grading for summer semester
reviews.comment_content:
Contents are similar to previous semesters, delivered in 11 days for this summer semester.
- Python Basics
- Data Structures
- Control Structures
- Functions and Classes
- Web Scrapping
- NumPy
- Pandas
- Matplotlib
- Guest sharing
- Final Project Presentation (last lecture)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Instructor: ZHOU, Jiali (PhD candidate)

Jiali is nice to students and tried his best to make the lecture interactive. I would say he really showed his passion in teaching and supporting students, which is better than some professors.

Perhaps without prior teaching experience, he often got stuck in some questions raised by other students, in which lectures would usually overrun a bit. His English, at least conversationally, was not that great, where he sometimes had to spent extra time for further explanation.

His teaching was therefore average.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grade were evaluated based on 4 components:
A. Class Participation: 20%
- replying questions in zoom chat / verbally
(He said he would count the number of answer for each person after each class.)

B. In-Class Exercise: 10%
- in-class exercise for each topic, submit via canvas
- graded on both submission and correctness
- count best 5 exercises

C. Assignments: 30%
- two assignments, each 15%
- Assignment 1: covers up to Data Structures
- Assignment 2: covers up to Functions and Classes

D. Final Project: 40%
The project requires you to bring together many of the concepts learnt in this course to solve a business analytical problem that interest you. You can form a small group (at most THREE students) to work on the project.
- Presentation: 10%
- Final Deliverables (codes+report): 20%
- Peer evaluation: 10% (full marks if individual group)

My scores:
Class parti: Not released
In-class exercise: 10/10
Assignment 1: 14.5/15
Assignment 2: 15/15
Final Project: 36/40 (9+17+10)
(Project score were not released originally, I emailed Jiali for my scores after I received my letter grade.)

Final Grade: A
(originally expected B+ or A-)
I would say the grading is quite lenient, didn’t expect scoring so high in the final project. I guess absolute grading makes a difference!
reviews.comment_workload:
There is a bit of workload tbh.
- 3.5 hours of lecture, 3 lectures per week (TuThSa)
- Need to take time to review the lecture materials before/after each lecture.
- In-class exercise due by midnight after the lecture.
- Only a few days for both of the assignments.
- Final project is quite demanding, as you have to prepare for the presentation, codes and final report in around 2-weeks time.

reviews.author: mcisatrueabc
reviews.title: DO NOT CHOOSE JAMES KWOK. HE'LL DESTROY YOUR GPA
reviews.comment_content: Some basic programming skills in python.
reviews.comment_teaching: To be honest, I don't think he possess adequate knowledge to teach ISOM3400. When he taught selenium in class, you can see that he was actually not so familiar to this topic. So if you want a knowledge professor who can solve you questions, go for JiaJia. The TA Sunny was generally helpful and nice who is willing to answer your questions.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading was not good as many people in space described. TBH at the very beginning I chose James's class because people said his grades were better than JiaJia's. I scored mean in nearly all the assignments and in class exercise, I still ended up having a C+. But my friends in JiaJia's class told me his grade was surprisingly quite decent this year, at least better than James's. So don't blindly believe that James's grades are better than JiaJia's. He seems to be nice but he is literally a killer this year. I don't know what happened to him this year
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is fair to a 3 credit course. I had an individual assignments and a group assignments. Also got 4 in class exercises. Overall the workload was manageable to an average student like me.

reviews.author: mylifesucks
reviews.comment_content:
1. Introduction to Python and Business Analytics Python Basics: Data, Data types, and Operators
2. Data Structures: Lists, Tuples, and Dictionaries
3. Control Structures: if, for, while, and try statements
4. Functions and Classes
5. Web Scraping
6. NumPy Arrays and Vectorized Computation Data Wrangling with pandas
7. Data Visualization with matplotlib and seaborn
reviews.comment_teaching:
Tbh, I don't think his accent is really a big issue. However, I think that the imbalance of difficulty of assignment and the final exam is the biggest problem. Although he may say that the assignment and the exam are easy, his lecture material doesn't help a lot. Even I've done all the extra exercise and reviewed all his material, it's still very hard or even impossible for me to finish the assignments and the exam. You will feel extremely confused and frustrated when you try to do this assignments and exam. In fact, I don't think it's a friendly course to programming language starter.

Despite that, I think he is a nice professor. It's easy to reach out to him. He is willing to answer our question as well.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is quite fair.
I got full credit of the in-class exercise and both assignments (which is 60% in total). However, I don't know my final exam score (which I think is extremely bad...). I got a B at last. Kinda fair.
reviews.comment_workload:
Moderate workload. You may need to spend more efforts and time on this course than expected.

A. In-class Exercises (20%)
B. Assignments (20% * 2)
C. Final Exam (40%)

reviews.author: Khchbk
reviews.comment_content: Great course design as foundation for data analysis and data mining. Could be a little hard to handle at the beginning if python is your first programming language learnt.
reviews.comment_teaching: Patient, explanations are generally clear but often goes over difficult concepts rather quickly for beginners.
reviews.comment_grading: Very nice grading for online exams.
reviews.comment_workload: Weekly quiz must attend or else you will lose credit. Quizzes are sometimes difficult but James is lenient on submission time if you make a request. One individual assignment one group assignment. Final exams done online this semester.

reviews.author: Ankit
reviews.title: Interesting class. SUPER useful for job and recruiting. Horrible teaching. Do not recommend for beginners in coding
reviews.comment_content: Interesting content. Horrible slides. If you have no experience in Python, it was nearly impossible to learn from the lecture slides
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof was a genius but was not good at teaching...He did a poor job at explaining and most of the times I had to rely on the TA's (who were Angels sent from God because they were so helpful)
reviews.comment_grading: I mean, its coding. So if you get the code right, or structure it correctly you will get rewarded. However, I struggled heavily with the class so I ended up doing horrible
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload was okay and we had many take home tests with plenty of time to finish them.

However if you were struggling with understanding how to take the python from theory to application, it was very diffficult because many times, the last questions in the take home were nearly impossible.

reviews.author: asdfghjkl
reviews.title: 正正常常咁
reviews.comment_content: python入門 今個sem主要用google colab 砌下啲code咁樣
reviews.comment_teaching:
James人好好 好樂於解答問題 有咩都可以問 我覺得大致上都教得好好 幾清晰 可能因為個course係beginner嘅程度 所以如果你有其他好奇/advance啲嘅野 佢會叫你google lol

TA Bosco把聲幾好聽 但lab有時有啲1999 因為時間唔夠 所以你預佢講解唔到太多 同埋佢assignment改得好認真 喊出聲
reviews.comment_grading:
14% inclass ex
58% assignments
28% final
inclass ex同assignment嘅mean全部都好高 (下面括號嘅係mean)
1. inclass ex多數拎滿分 9個入面計最高分7個 多數都簡單 係嗰堂教嘅野 (~14/14)
2. Assignments有3份 (#1 individual: 22.1/24, #2 group: 15.2/17, #3 group: 15.9/17)
3. final (16.33/28, SD:3.33)
我overall mean(~85%), B
其實掂mean有B係好grade 但明明已經85% 私心覺得唔算好靚
reviews.comment_workload:
就係嗰3份assignment 有啲assignment(ATM) 好鬼複雜 做死人 利申第一次見python 做到成隻狗咁都低mean好多
同埋佢教就教得淺 但實際上你要用好多時間去砌 你真係要自己google

其他大致上都冇野 你只要上堂 跟到佢教緊咩就得

reviews.author: mushroom
reviews.comment_content: Some basic syntax in the beginning, and after like 3 weeks, the contents are very difficult and hard to understand. Attending lab sessions help a bit, but really need to google and practice by yourself.
reviews.comment_teaching: Don't know what he's teaching lol. And many of my classmates have the same feelings. The contents are not well organized and James makes it even messier. His tone is also very low and I often felt sleepy.
reviews.comment_grading:
No midterm
3 assignments (1 individual, 2 group assignments)
The first one is easy and you can ask James or TA to check if you need to improve something. I think this is quite good, James gave a lot of advice and responded very often.
in-class exercise (choose the highest 7 scores, sometimes group, sometimes individual)
Have peer evaluation but since this semester allows pass/fail, some students just don't give a fk.
reviews.comment_workload: Quite high since he only gave us 10 days to finish group assignments. I mean, it should be at least 2 weeks for me. We have to discuss it and assign parts to each other and also debug. 10 days and close to midterm weak is just crazy. Especially under the circumstance that some groupmates (assigned by them) are not participating. Also, we have to record a video to present our code.

reviews.author: YH.N
reviews.comment_content:
There are two main parts in this lecture.
1. basic knowledge of Python
2. how to use Python in data mining

really great examples and explanation in materials and lectures
reviews.comment_teaching:
Li is just fancy.
He is patient and always ready to help us with any puzzles.
the material, lab and assignment he prepares are appropriate for beginner as well as the students with some background knowledge.
reviews.comment_grading: quite good and fair
reviews.comment_workload:
a little bit heavy.
It includes 10 labs, 6 assignments, one of which is for group assignment and face to face lectures.

reviews.author: tatgor
reviews.comment_content:
Programming:
- Data Structures
- Loops
- Functions
- Classes

Business Analytics:
- Numpy
- Pandas
- Matplotlib
- Seaborn

With some basic knowledge about Python, I expect to learn some more advanced functions for data analytics. But Jia Jia spent almost 2 months on the basic programming and 1 month left for the rest. It doesn't seem like a 3000 level course to me at all and the content is not very related to BA. I think you can learn more about python by taking ISOM2500 taught by Prof. Wan.
reviews.comment_teaching: Jia Jia is nice and he is willing to answer questions after the class. His accent is ok but the voice is rather monotonic. Basically, he just opens a ppt and tells you how to use those functions without any demonstration.The ppt is also not well written. Sometimes it is quite hard to follow. He goes too detailed about how to use some functions. I think it is unnecessary because we can google and learn it. Therefore, the teaching was behind the schedule and he cut the machine learning and web scraping part.
reviews.comment_grading:
Lab Exercises: 10%
Class participation: 5%
Assignment: 60%
Final: 25%

I don't know whether the grading is good or not. The mean score of the lab and assignment is generally very high and the prof didn't release the score of the final. But I'm happy with my grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Lab every week and 5 assignments through out the semester. The lab is great and the TA is nice. Although, the lab overrun sometimes. Both lab material and assignment is well prepared. It usually takes one day to finish an assignment (except for the last one). It is challenging but rewarding to finish it on your own.

reviews.author: Lainey
reviews.comment_content:
Introduction to Course and Programming

Introduction to Python and Business Analytics

Data, data types and operators

Data structures: Lists and Tuples

Data structures: Dictionaries

Control statements: if

Control statements: for, while

Control statements: try-except

Functions and Classes

Web automation – Selenium

Data Exploration  - pandas

Data Exploration - matplotlib
reviews.comment_teaching: James is really a nice person, he answers students' question actively, and give us a lot of in class and after class exercise. Also he took students' advice to enhance his teaching. In the lesson, James will play the video teaching he recorded in advance, and demonstrate the coding again to us after the video. The content is easy to understand. Besides, the TA, Ray is also very nice, he responded to email very quickly and patiently answered my questions through zoom for assignments.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignment 1(individual)  - 15%
Assignment 2 (group) - 15%
In class exercise (total 3, count the best 2)
- 30%
Final exam - 40%
reviews.comment_workload: I think the workload is fair, you need to finish two assignment, one for individual and one for group, for me, since I am a beginner for programming, it took me several days to finish the individual assignment and group project, but I have to say that these two assignments help me a lot to grasp the content taught in the class more deeply. Additionally, the extra in-class exercise is really useful to help you get familiar with basic python. All you need to do is practice for having a good grade.

reviews.author: smdpmesm
reviews.title: Rubbish course
reviews.comment_content:
直至最後2個禮拜都仲係較近d basic logic
臨尾教唔切 一堂飛一個library
基本上我都係上YouTube學返
reviews.comment_teaching:
zoom堂完全冇出過樣
成堂都係del bug同答d 解左好多次嘅問題
超級拖時間
把聲好似機械人 又慢又悶
2X播放都嫌慢。。。
搞到最後最難嘅完全教唔切 要cut內容
reviews.comment_grading:
做齊所有野
但係冇一個有出分
final考嘅嘢上堂都係冇講過
9成課堂內容唔考 最後1成內容就係考試內容
但係佢又教唔切
利申：ICT prog滿分都搞成咁，大家睇路。。。
reviews.comment_workload:
睇你識唔識打
隨時del bug玩足你一日
有exercises 同2份大hw
有部分題目上堂/lab有講
但係有幾個分題都幾難下 因為佢上堂notes 冇教過
後尾我直接去YouTube學仲識得多d
搞到要上2倍堂

reviews.author: stolceins
reviews.title: Not good for zoom lectures
reviews.comment_content:
Basics of Python:
data structures, control flows, class and functions
Packages:
NumPy, Pandas, matlab, seaborn, Python Selenium (web scraping)

Jia jia did not teach how to use selenium on Google Colab and VS code, and the exam required students to use Jupyter only, it might not be a problem

P.S. the content is almost the same as ISOM3390 programming for R, another course taught by Jia Jia
reviews.comment_teaching: Not too much to say about Jia Jia's teaching. Since I have taken the R course a semester before, I could catch up quite well which his teaching. Although the pace is slow for those who have programming backgrounds, he went through all the required points in the lecture notes.
reviews.comment_grading:
In-class exercises (x5): 20%
Assignment (x2): 40%
Final exam: 40%

Exercises are easy, the professor would go through the first half part and students finish another half after class. Students have one (sometimes two) days to finish. Assignments are not difficult, could finish in 1-2 days. And if you have taken his R course, you may find the selenium questions very easy. Since the questions are the same as R's exercises, just an easier and shorter version. This time, prof. gave a lot of restrictions, including only 2 submission attempts, using only what you taught (exclude the optional parts of the lecture notes) on the lesson.

The exam is awful in terms of the time limit and the difficulty. 2 hours for 1 SQ and 3 LQ, the purposes of the programs students need to code are easy to understand. But it takes a very long time to process the instructions and follow the flow stated by the questions. Also, unlike the assignment, the question using selenium is much more difficult as it requires additional handling about some conditions which you have never seen in lecture notes or assignments before. After the exam, I took around 3-4 hours to finish the whole exam with all expected output met.
reviews.comment_workload: Light for a programming course. Yet, if you want to learn a bit more about python, the exercises given by the professor are not enough. Also, students could only use what Jia Jia taught in class in all exercises, assignments and exam, the questions themselves are not difficult to finish.

reviews.author: Nggmeishi07
reviews.title: One of the worst courses I have even taken
reviews.comment_content:
Starting with very basic python knowledge. Then moving on to more advanced topics (i.e Panda, lambda and web scrapping)
The content may seem to be easy, but it is definitely not ( Mostly because of the horrible delivery of professor )
If you do not know any python before this course, I suggest you to learn it by yourself first before taking this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I have never experienced teaching like this( to be fair) Professor Jia's english is so hard to understand , mostly because of his accent. I think if he uses mandarin to deliver his message it will be much better ( however he uses english ,which leads to bad delivery)
DO NOT TAKE HIS CLASS IF YOU ARE A BEGINNER OR ELSE YOU WILL MESS UP LIKE  I DID
reviews.comment_grading:
In class exercise - 20%
2 assignments - 40%
Final - 40%

As you can see the distribution is kinda crazy , as if you mess up one of the 3 components , then you are screwed.

The final is super hard, there is too little time for me to finish the paper. The level of difficulty is far above what he taught us during class, so it is nearly impossible to finish. Also, there are a lot of restrictions during the exam (i.e cannot use google colab, only Jupyter is allowed, cannot use Python set) So you are suggested to grab all the possible point in the in class exercises and assignments.

As I just finished my final today, I will update grading leniency after receiving my grade. (in which I don't expect much )
UPDATE : hardly messed up , got a c- and I think it can be better than that. Well at least not a D haha)
reviews.comment_workload:
Well the workload is pretty decent.
You need to submit the in class exercise one day after it has been posted . And usually Professor Jia will provide some answers to the exercise during class so there are not much left for you to work on your own ( which is nice)
For the assignments, although being super lengthy and hard, there will be sufficient time for you to finish the task since the assignment will normally be launched a couple weeks before its deadline.

reviews.author: imcat
reviews.title: Surprisingly Good Grade
reviews.comment_content:
The course is an advanced version of ISOM2020.
I would say, the contents could be improved by making the lecture context to be more about "Business Analytics".
1. Python Basics
2. Data Structures
3. Control Structures
4. Functions and Classes
(All ISOM2020 stuff + advanced applications of dictionary, detailed stuff about Classes + list/dictionary comprehensions)
---
5. Web Scraping (BeautifulSoup and Selenium)
6. Numpy and Vectorized Operations
7. Data Wrangling with Pandas
8. Data Visualization (Matplotlib, Seaborn is optional)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Jia is a very nice person. I don't think his accent affected his teaching actually, given the lecture ipynbs are enough to follow through his teaching.

Pro tip: ask questions after class by sending him and the TA an email. I think Prof articulate stuff way better in writing.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme:
1. 20% In-class Exercises
2. 40% Individual Assignment (x1, 5 questions)
3. 40% Final Exam (2-hour, 4 questions)

> For in-class exercises, I think virtually all people got around 38-40.
> For Individual Assignment, no statistics released. I would say you need to Google a lot and preferably go through all the stuff that the Prof has taught around the time he released the assignment to be able to finish them with all expected output met.
> For Final Exam... it is very difficult and lengthy. Do not expect you can answer all the questions. I left a few sub tasks completely blank. DO TRY TO ATTEMPT ALL OF THE QUESTIONS cuz I think the grading was made more lenient.

- Got nearly full for the 60% (In-class Exercises and Individual Assignment)
- No score released for final exam, only released overall course grade
reviews.comment_workload:
Overall light workload. No attendance.

Prof went through 1/3 of the in-class exercises during lectures. We had to submit the exercises by 23:59 the next day the exercise released.

For individual assignment, we got around 2 weeks to finish it.

For Final Exam:
1. GO THROUGH everything:
> Lecture Notes: you better understand all lecture ipynbs completely;
> In-class Exercises: re-do all of them to have a solid understanding of what Prof expects
> Individual Assignment: re-do and try to think about what more-difficult stuff he can come up with in a similar context

2. DO NOT PANIC when you cannot finish even the first question (Yes that's me). SKIP the questions first if you find you're clueless in around 10 minutes. Deal with topics that you find more familiar with first.

3. REMEMBER you HAVE to use COMPREHENSIONS otherwise you can lose marks.

reviews.author: DRose
reviews.title: Bad syllabus design but nice grade
reviews.comment_content:
1. Python Basics
2. Data Structures
3. Control Structures
4. Functions and Classes
5. Web Scraping
6. Numpy
7. Data Manipulation
8. Data Visualisation

The syllabus emphasised too much on basic concepts, more time should be allocated in teaching new concepts like beautiful soup in web scraping and pandas in data manipulation.
reviews.comment_teaching: I can't deny the fact that Jia jia is an intelligent guy in coding, yet he fails to deliver the materials with his heavy accent. I believe he can do better if he is allowed to use Mandarin to conduct the lectures. However, considering the other professor that teaches this course have his own problems as well and hearing rumours that the other professor gives out worse grades, I didn't drop Jia jia's class despite the problems I've mentioned. Meanwhile, I think he spent too much time on the basic stuffs  (i.e. first three topics), which most of us have learnt in ISOM 2020. The bad time management made Jia jia rushed the syllabus in November, ultimately leading to confusion and loads of questions after class about the new topics.
reviews.comment_grading:
In class exercises (30%)
Individual Assessment (30%)
Final Exam (40%)

In class exercise 1 (My score: 40/40, Mean: 38.98/40)
In class exercise 2 (My score: 38/40, Mean: 37.89/40)
In class exercise 3 (My score: 40/40, Mean: 38.55/40)
In class exercise 4 (My score: 40/40, Mean: 36.39/40)
Individual Assessment (My score: 100/100, Mean: 95.35/100)

Unfortunately, Jia jia didn't release any statistics of the final exam, including my own score. he just gave me the letter grade straightaway. I ended up getting A+. As you can see, the mean scores of the exercises and assessment are very high, try to aim full marks in every one of them or else there's no way for you to get a good letter grade considering the competitiveness of this course.
reviews.comment_workload: Honestly not much. First of all there's no attendance requirement, so you can basically watch the lecture videos. Though the deadline of the in class exercises is the day after they're released,  Jia jia usually spend some lecture time to 'discuss' the questions in the in class exercises (i.e. he basically gives you the answer of half of the exercise). You just need to spend an hour at most to finish the remaining questions, or you can simply work with your friends as he encourages you to do so. However, Jia jia will not give you any tips for the individual assessment, you are expected to work on your own this time . Do not try to copy your friends' work as it might result in plagiarism. For your information, I spent like a week on it and you have three weeks to work on it, you have more than enough time and Google could help you a lot. For final exam, just do the extra questions the night before and make cheat sheets for the codes that you are not familiar with and you'll be fine. All in all, workload looks fair if you can follow his teaching progress.

reviews.author: normal person
reviews.title: really useful course
reviews.comment_content: learnt useful packages and syntaxes, good for beginners, u do NOT need any coding experience for this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
professor is so kind and helpful, he answers question quickly.
since the course is relatively easy, there is not much to complain about.
ta is also quite helpful, but he only works on working hours. (ends replying emails sharp after 430)
reviews.comment_grading:
grading is lenient!
exam is easy, but make sure u meet the requirements and prepare for the open book. also remember to train wpm as it will be tight
reviews.comment_workload: not much workload, it will be 15 min work if u have python experience.
